reaction.reactionmeddrallt: Varicose veins of lower extremities with inflammation

summary.narrativeincludeclinical:
30 Oct 2006 Initial report received: Legal case from an attorney: A patient developed osteonecrosis of the jaw while on Zometa (zoledronic acid) therapy for multiple myeloma (diagnosed in 2000) since 2003. In Oct 2004, the patient had a dental procedure that included the removal of a bridge. After the procedure, the patient's wound would not heal and she was subsequently diagnosed with osteonecrosis of the jaw. The patient experienced exposed dead bone in her jaw, physical disfigurement, difficulty in ingesting food normally, and significant and severe pain.
Follow-up information received on 15 Dec 2008 from the attorney inclusive of medical records from the dentist: The patient was on therapy with Aredia (pamidronate) and Zometa (dosage, indication and therapy dates not provided). Dental records on 03 May 2005 indicated the patient was compromised due to subgingival decay. Patient was informed that #2 and #3 were compromised so long term stability could not be sure, and patient opted to try to save and keep the teeth. Dental records on 21 Apr 2006 indicated that the patient's last visit one year prior had open bone exposed on the mandibular left ridge. The patient had two teeth extracted (at a different office) and the wound opened on the ridge shortly after. The dentist removed the surface of the bone and sutured it closed. The patient's condition worsened and oral rinses (not specified) were administered. Dental records on 11 Oct 2006 indicated the patient felt #23 was getting loose just like #22 did before falling out. A panoramic x-ray was taken and the necrosis seemed to have advanced more. Drainage point was noted on the ridge 1 centimeter posterior to #23 and the patient was given amoxicillin. Dental records on 25 Sep 2007 indicated the open bone site had expanded approximately another seven to eight millimeters, the borders were red and irritated, and the patient reported slight pain for the first time. An x-ray showed worsening of necrosis, #23 was very loose, bone was not very dense around #24, encroaching on mandibular canal, and cortical plate appeared more dense. Dental records on 10 Jan 2008 indicated the necrotic area was worsening and another tooth #23 was about to be lost. Dental records on 22 Apr 2008 indicated the necrotic area was somewhat better than the last visit but still "a very serious looking area." Mobility was noted on #24, and #23 was very mobile and was to be exfoliated soon. No further information provided.
Follow up received 04 May 2009 combined with information received on 06 May 2009 from the consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records. On an unspecified date the patient experienced ovarian failure. The patient underwent kyphoplasty in Jan 2004. She had multiple thoracic and lumbar compression fractures. She was also noted to have osteoporosis. Records dated Aug 2004 indicated that the patient had a stem cell transplant. She also had complaints of weakness and nausea. The patient also had a mouth sore and complained of esophagitis. She was noted to have fever and pancytopenia. Records dated 28 Jan 2005 indicated that a PA and lateral chest demonstrated generalized osteopenia.
Follow up received 14 May 2009 from the consumer's attorney inclusive of dental records. Records dated 15 Oct 2008 indicated that the ridge was healing after necrotic segment was removed.
Follow up received on 25 Jan 2010 combined with records received 01 Feb 2010 from the consumer's attorney inclusive of dental and medical records. Treatment medications updated with clindamycin, Peridex (chlorhexidine gluconate) and Vioxx (rofecoxib). Updated patient's relevant history to include: hemicolectomy, otitis media, allergic rhinitis, sinusitis and bronchitis. Records dated 20 Jan 2004 indicated the patient had a CBC panel done that showed a platelet count of 436,000, which was thought to be a little high. The patient also had an EKG done which showed a left axis deviation. The patient was scheduled for a Kyphoplasty on 22 Jan 2004 (outcome unspecified) and was diagnosed with multiple compression fractures of the "T and L spine" and joint pain.
Follow up received on 12 Feb 2010 and 15 Feb 2010 from the consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records. Medical history was updated to include historical medications Leucovorin (folinic acid) and 5-FU (fluorouracil). Concomitant medication details were updated. Medical reports dated 07 Feb 2007 reported patient had venous insufficiency in the left greater saphenous vein. Report dated 23 Feb 2009 noted diverticulosis of the sigmoid colon, polyps in the rectum and polypectomy.
Follow up received on 26 Feb 2010 from the consumer's attorney inclusive of radiology records. A bilateral lower extremity venous sonograph done on 02 Apr 2008 revealed the greater saphenous on the right had insufficiency.
Follow-up received on 01 Apr 2010 from the consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records. On 22 Oct 2004, a follow-up bone marrow examination, right posterior iliac crest, aspirate and biopsy demonstrated normocellular marrow for the patient's age with satisfactory erythro- and myelopoiesis, eosinophilia and mild megakaryocytic hypoplasia. Peripheral blood showed pancytopenia. On 01 Aug 2005, a follow-up bone marrow exam demonstrated normocellular bone marrow with active trilineage hematopoiesis. Peripheral blood showed decreased red cells and platelets. On 09 Feb 2005, a CT examination of the paranasal sinuses suggested a possibility of acute bilateral maxillary and right ethmoid sinusitis.
Follow up received on 20 Apr 2010 via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records. Current condition included hypercholesterolemia and internal hemorrhoids. Records dated 19 Oct 2005 showed tubular adenoma of colon. Records dated 24 Jun 2009 showed the patient had mild fecal incontinence likely related to anorectal dysfunction. The patient was recently diagnosed with a rectocele.
Follow-up report received on 09 Jun 2010 via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records. Past medical history included family history of high blood pressure, emphysema, tuberculosis, and arthritis. Concomitant medications updated. A chest x-ray performed on 15 Jan 2004 showed very poor inspiratory effort and bibasilar subsegmental atelectasis. No further information was provided.
Follow up received on 12 Oct 2010 from the consumers attorney inclusive of medical records: Medical records dated 20 Dec 2000 indicated the patient had colonoscopy performed which revealed mild internal hemmorhoid. On 24 Jun 2009, patient had 2+ ankle edema. Medical records also reported that the patient had hypercholesterolemia and was prescribed lipitor.
Follow-up received on 17 Jun 2011 via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records: Records dated 28 Aug 2003 stated that the patient was diagnosed with corneal arcus. On 19 Jan 2007 she complained about eye burn. No new medical information was provided.
Follow up received on 07 Feb 2012 via a consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records: Records dated 27 Jan 2011 noted that patient experienced severe leg cramps and leg pain. Patient underwent laser therapy for venous insufficiency on 22 Feb 2011. Records dated 01 Mar 2011 noted that patient experienced dyspnea. Records dated 11 Apr 2011 noted that patient experienced coronary artery disease. Patient underwent CABG (coronary artery bypass graft) on an unspecified date. The outcomes of the events were not reported.
Follow up received on 13 Feb 2012 via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records: The medical record dated 02 Oct 2008 stated that the patient had lesion left mandible and inflammatory conditions of jaw. The outcome of the events was not reported.
Follow-up received on 22 Jun 2012 via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records. Records dated 16 Jan 2012 stated that the patient had stress incontinence, cystocele and uterine prolapse. Records further stated that the patient underwent total vaginal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, vaginal vault suspension and appendectomy. The outcome of the events was not provided.
Follow up received on 14 Aug 2012 from physician via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records: Record dated 03 Aug 2011 noted decreased vision, cataract, anxiety and swelling, also patient underwent back surgery, extra capsular cataract extraction and intraocular lens implantation in right eye. The outcomes of the events were not reported.
Follow-up report received from the consumer’s attorney on 07 Dec 2012 inclusive of medical records: Record dated 09 Oct 2009 noted that the patient had leg aches and varicose veins of lower extremities with inflammation. Outcome of the events was not reported.
summary.sendercomment: Medical assessment: Review of available data reported in this legal case does not allow for proper causality assessments.
